data.question: Who are the authors of the paper discussing direct C(sp2)–C(sp3) cross-coupling?
data.answer: Jay J. Dunsford, Ewan R. Clark, and Michael J. Ingleson

data.question: What is the significance of developing new C(sp2)–C(sp3) bonds according to the paper?
data.answer: The generation of new C(sp2)–C(sp3) bonds is of great significance for the preparation of complex molecules.

data.question: What makes zinc systems attractive for the generation of C(sp2)–C(sp3) bonds?
data.answer: Zinc systems are attractive due to the low cost, low toxicity, and environmentally benign nature of zinc.

data.question: What was the unexpected outcome of the reaction between diphenylzinc and 3-methoxybenzyl bromide?
data.answer: The unexpected outcome was the complete consumption of 3-methoxybenzyl bromide and the formation of a single new species, consistent with the C(sp2)–C(sp3) cross-coupling product.

data.question: How does the presence of coordinating ethereal solvents affect the C(sp2)–C(sp3) cross-coupling reaction?
data.answer: The presence of coordinating ethereal solvents drastically suppresses the reactivity of the C(sp2)–C(sp3) cross-coupling reaction.

data.question: What was the role of diaryl zinc reagents in iron-catalyzed C(sp2)–C(sp3) cross-coupling transformations?
data.answer: Diaryl zinc reagents were used as additives in iron-catalyzed C(sp2)–C(sp3) cross-coupling transformations to examine their influence.

data.question: Is the observed reactivity in the model reaction impurity-driven?
data.answer: No, the observed reactivity in the model reaction is not impurity-driven.

data.question: Can tertiary alkyl halides be readily coupled with diphenylzinc at ambient temperature?
data.answer: Yes, tertiary alkyl halides can be readily coupled with diphenylzinc at ambient temperature in exceedingly short reaction times.

data.question: What was the yield of the cross-coupling product when using dimesitylzinc with 3-methoxybenzyl bromide?
data.answer: The yield of the cross-coupling product was 82%.

data.question: Does the addition of a stoichiometric amount of an aliphatic ether significantly suppress reactivity?
data.answer: Yes, the addition of even a stoichiometric amount of an aliphatic ether significantly suppresses reactivity.

data.question: What was the major product formed when using 6-bromo-1-hexene in cross-coupling with diphenylzinc?
data.answer: The major product was phenylcyclohexane, derived from an endo radical cyclization of a radical intermediate.

data.question: Is the cross-coupling process mediated by radical intermediates?
data.answer: Yes, the cross-coupling process appears to be mediated by radical intermediates.

data.question: What effect does increasing the Lewis acidity at zinc have on the cross-coupling reaction?
data.answer: Increasing the Lewis acidity at zinc favors the formation of adducts and is consistent with the observed coupling suppression with halide-bridged zincate species.

data.question: Was the use of chlorobenzene as a solvent viable for the cross-coupling process?
data.answer: Yes, chlorobenzene was also a viable solvent for the cross-coupling process.

data.question: What was the outcome of attempting to trap radical intermediates with 9,10-dihydroanthracene?
data.answer: The attempt failed, and quantitative cross-coupling was observed within 10 minutes at ambient temperature.

data.question: Did the reaction between diphenylzinc and 3-methoxybenzyl bromide require the addition of a catalyst?
data.answer: No, the reaction proceeded in the absence of a catalyst.

data.question: What was the yield of the isolated product when scaling up the synthesis of the cross-coupling product 3a?
data.answer: The yield of the isolated product was 93% when scaling up the synthesis.

data.question: Is the cross-coupling reaction highly solvent dependent?
data.answer: Yes, the cross-coupling reaction is highly solvent dependent.

data.question: What was the major challenge in cross-coupling with tertiary alkyl halides according to the paper?
data.answer: The major challenge was that C(sp2)–C(sp3) cross-coupling with tertiary alkyl halides is extremely challenging even using state-of-the-art transition-metal-catalyzed procedures.

data.question: What was the purpose of using diphenylzinc obtained from multiple sources and of varying purity?
data.answer: The purpose was to probe the influence of trace impurities on the observed reactivity.
